ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A very thorough overview of central theoretical texts in International Relations, paired with more empirical insights into topical matters of security

This course was an excellent introduction to the literature on international security. I have a much better command of the classic contributions to the study of international politics, a deeper familiarity with the key debates, and a clearer sense of the kinds of research that IR scholars do now. The course also dealt with methodological and epistemological debates in helpful and thought-provoking ways.
Working knowledge of international security issues.

The course opened up a new realm of thought on international relations and security. I learned how to view and analyze states' actions on the global stage, the motivations and reasoning behind their actions.
A theoretical approach to IR problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Monteiro expressed disappointment with the way he balanced the security and theoretical aspects of this course, but I actually enjoyed the way he performed that balancing act. Wonderful and engaging discussions, no weaknesses. Very heavy reading load per class, however.

I think the course is well-structured as it is. I recognize that it is challenging to balance the interests of the PhD students and those of the Jackson school students (the former being more focused on theory, latter more interested in contemporary events etc.), but Professor Monteiro does a very good job of this. I would encourage Professor Monteiro to use the first part of each class meeting to give a lecture, like the one that he did at the beginning of the session on nuclear weapons. I think this was helpful because it made sure that everyone was (more or less) on the same page in the subsequent discussion.
The course load was heavy for a Global Affairs student. Thought-provoking questions to accompany the readings would help students hone in on the relevant points each week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This was the best course that I have taken at Yale and I would certainly recommend it to another student, irrespective of their subfield.
Yes, for anyone interested in learning about global conflict and cooperation. The course gives deep insight into historical and current events in international security.
Yes, if interested in developing a theoretical background in IR.
